awd_titl_txt: Preparing Future Mathematics and Science Teachers through the Noyce Scholarship Program at Savannah State University and Savannah Technical College
awd_abstract_narration:
For this Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Phase I project, investigators from Savannah State University (SSU) will work closely with partner institutions to recruit, mentor, educate, and certify students to become highly qualified STEM middle school and high school teachers to help alleviate workforce shortages in this area of national need. The project team will help place graduates from the program in high-need schools and then provide them with important and timely support when they enter the STEM teaching profession. Responding to the high demand for STEM teachers in the Savannah Chatham County Public School System (SCCPSS), SSU will partner with SCCPSS and two-year school Savannah Technical College (STC) to increase the number of high quality, technology education-certified STEM teachers prepared to teach in high-need schools.  In particular, this Noyce project will prepare at least twenty-eight (28) undergraduate mathematics and engineering majors and eight (8) STEM professionals to become certified middle school or high school teachers of mathematics and/or science grades 6 - 12. SSU's activities as a Historically Black University with a student body of 94% African-American not only will enhance STEM workforce diversity, but will also contribute to a broader understanding of how teacher preparation programs can be tailored to reach and prepare African-American and other underrepresented minority students for successful STEM teaching careers.

The overall program will employ several interconnected  components to recruit, train, mentor, and retain new highly qualified  STEM teachers. These strategical components will include: (i) promoting extensive outreach and targeted recruitment activities; (ii) providing internships and summer programs (workshops, observation, and hands-on teaching experiences) for first and second year undergraduates as part of the recruitment process to generate interest in teaching; (iii) funding scholarships for selected junior and senior STEM majors who wish to become teachers; (iv) offering a challenging, problem solving, inquiry based, collaborating learning environment to address real-world applications through SSU's established teacher education program; (v) implementing field experience activities to aid the training and retaining process; (vi) orchestrating professional development, mentoring opportunities, and other induction support to ensure a successful transition to teaching and improved retention for the early career teacher graduates; and (vii) researching and assessing the effects of these initiatives. The assessment tools are designed to provide both quantitative and qualitative information as a basis for research and continuous improvement of the program.

por.por_cntn:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) Noyce Grant project at Savannah State University (SSU), embarked on a visionary quest in 2014 to mitigate the acute shortage of qualified secondary school teachers in mathematics, science, and engineering technology. Over the span of nine years, this pioneering initiative sought not only to address this gap but also to revolutionize STEM education in underserved districts, fostering a cadre of educators diverse in background but unified in their commitment to inspiring the next generation of learners.

 

Bridging Gaps, Building Futures

Objective 1: Amplifying Diversity Among Educators

The project aimed to certify 32 diverse Noyce Scholarship participants, drawing from a pool of math, science, and engineering majors from SSU. Surpassing its target, the program proudly supported 54 scholars by 2023. The diversity of the cohort was a testament to the project's commitment to inclusivity, ensuring that students across various demographics could see themselves reflected in their educators, fostering a more inclusive learning environment.

  • Target: 32 scholarships for math, science, and engineering majors.
  • Outcome: 54 scholarships awarded, surpassing the target by 68.75%.

Objective 2: Tapping into the Untapped

Recognizing the untapped reservoir of potential among STEM professionals and retirees, the project offered stipends as an incentive for these individuals to transition into teaching roles. This novel approach not only enriched classrooms with real-world experiences but also played a crucial role in diversifying the teaching workforce, bringing a plethora of perspectives and life lessons into the educational sphere.

  • Target: 8 stipends for transitioning STEM professionals into teaching roles.
  • Outcome: Achieved the goal, thereby enriching the teaching workforce with experienced professionals from various STEM fields.

Transformative Actions, Tangible Outcomes

Proactive Recruitment and Engagement

The project's aggressive recruitment strategy, coupled with the Summer Educational Internship Program (SEIP), magnetized individuals towards a teaching vocation. Early engagement initiatives, including immersive field observation experiences, provided an authentic glimpse into the teaching profession, nurturing a profound commitment among participants. This early exposure was critical in solidifying the resolve of potential educators, ensuring they were not just stepping into teaching but were walking into their calling with open eyes and full hearts.

  • Summer Educational Internship Program (SEIP): Engaged over 100 students across the project lifespan, offering them a firsthand glimpse into the teaching profession.
  • Field Observation Experiences: Facilitated over 200 field observation days, connecting aspiring teachers with real-world classroom environments.

Financial Support as a Catalyst

The scholarships and stipends provided were more than just financial aid; they were enablers of dreams, allowing participants to focus on their training without the burden of financial constraints. This support was instrumental in ensuring that the scholars were not only prepared academically but were also mentally and emotionally invested in their future roles as educators.

  • Financial Support: Distributed over $540,000 in scholarships and stipends, removing financial barriers for 54 aspiring STEM teachers.

A Comprehensive Educational Scaffold

The College of Education and the College of Science and Technology at SSU were the academic backbone of the initiative, offering a curriculum rich in problem-solving, inquiry-based activities, and collaborative learning. This approach ensured that the educators were not just teachers of content but facilitators of critical thinking, creativity, and innovation.

Intellectual Merit and Broader Impacts: A Dual Legacy

The intellectual merit of the project lay in its strategic foresight to address the dearth of qualified STEM teachers through a comprehensive and inclusive approach. By fostering a diverse group of educators, the project not only elevated the quality of STEM education but also contributed significantly to narrowing the achievement gap for underrepresented minority groups. Personalized mentoring and specialized training ensured that the Noyce Scholars were well-equipped to cater to the diverse needs of their students, understanding and integrating cultural nuances into their teaching methodologies.

The broader impacts of the initiative are profound, contributing significantly to the professional development of STEM educators and the overall enhancement of STEM education in high-need districts. The success in recruiting and retaining a diverse cohort of teachers has left an indelible mark on the community, igniting a spark of inspiration among students, and providing them with role models who mirror their own experiences and aspirations.

Looking Ahead: A Legacy of Inspiration

As the NSF Noyce Grant project at Savannah State University concludes its current chapter in 2023, its legacy is far from over. The strides made in transforming STEM education, through a holistic approach to teacher recruitment, education, and support, have not only met the set objectives but have also raised the bar for excellence in STEM teacher preparation. The lessons learned and the successes achieved serve as a beacon of hope and a blueprint for future endeavors aimed at cultivating the next generation of STEM educators. This initiative stands as a testament to the power of vision, commitment, and collaboration in creating transformative educational experiences that not only educate but inspire.


Last Modified: 02/22/2024
Modified by: Kisha R Aites
